awd_titl_txt: Using Bricklayer Coding and Visual Art to Engage Students in Learning Mathematics
awd_abstract_narration:
Among the challenges facing undergraduate science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education today, the instruction of mathematics is of special concern. Mathematics is often at the foundation of learning other STEM disciplines, yet introductory undergraduate mathematics courses tend to have high failure rates and present a barrier to success for many students, particularly for those from economically disadvantaged groups. Lack of interest and loss of self-confidence in mathematics is common among students. This project seeks to address these challenges by exploiting the close relationship between mathematical thinking and computational thinking. Computational thinking skills, such as breaking down problems into manageable parts, recognizing patterns, and developing step-by-step solution processes that can be programmed for a computer, are increasingly viewed as fundamental skills in the technology-driven world of the twenty-first century. In this Improving Undergraduate STEM Education Exploration & Design (IUSE E&D) project, researchers will design, implement, and assess a new interdisciplinary general-education course at the University of Nebraska a Omaha (UNO) that uses the visual arts to motivate students to develop mathematical and computational thinking skills. The course will be based on Bricklayer, an open-source educational ecosystem in which students learn to write programs that create two- and three-dimensional LEGO, Minecraft, and 3D-printed artifacts. Many such artifacts are based on mathematical patterns that the students themselves discover. In this inquiry-based learning environment, mathematical thinking is a means to an end rather than an end unto itself. It is expected that a positive experience in this gateway course will lead to more positive perceptions not only of mathematics, but also of computing and other STEM disciplines.

The project's key research objective is to investigate the educational impact of the new course in terms of students' interest and engagement in mathematics and other STEM disciplines while ensuring continued high standards of learning. Specifically, the research team will investigate the following research questions: (1) Do students express more interest in mathematics and STEM after participating in the new course? (2) Do students who take the new course plan to continue participating in STEM by taking further STEM courses? (3) Does participating in the new course increase students' confidence and self-efficacy with mathematics and STEM? and (4) Do students in the new class persevere in mastering the material at higher rates than in other introductory courses? Data sources will include interviews with instructors who teach the course, focus groups with student participants, assessments of students' mathematics content knowledge, as well as pre- and post-course student surveys that measure students' attitudes and beliefs about mathematics and interest in STEM coursework and careers. A within-subject design will be used to measure how the new course changes students' attitudes, self-efficacy, and interest while a between-subject design will compare these attributes between students in the new course and those taking the existing general education mathematics course.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The long-term goal of this project is to increase interest, participation, and persistence in the STEM disciplines by transforming how undergraduate students engage with and learn mathematics. In support of this goal we have achieved the following objectives:

  • MATH 1120: Mathematical and Computational Thinking was developed and approved as general education course. The course teaches math concepts through programming, where the output of the programs is visual art. Enrollment in MATH 1120 has steadily increased. A total of 726 students took the course between Spring 2018 and Spring 2021, taught by five different instructors. The course is popular enough that an instructor was hired into the math department specifically to ensure high quality instruction in this course.
  • The general education mathematics requirements were revised and renamed to quantitative literacy requirements. In addition to College Algebra (MATH 1220) and MATH 1120, two other new courses (MATH 1130: Quantitative Literacy and MATH 1530: Elementary Statistics) were introduced to meet these requirements. As an outcome of the expansion of gen ed math offerings, many courses across campus expanded their list of math prerequisites beyond college algebra. This opened pathways for students to engage in STEM courses. This was particularly true with introductory computing courses such as CSCI 1200: Computer Science Principles and CIST 1300: Introduction to Web Development but also more broadly, such as PSYCH 3130: Statistics for the Behavioral Sciences. 
  • The research team worked with Omaha’s Metropolitan Community College and local school districts to offer MATH 1120 beyond UNO, and for UNO credit.

As a research project in pursuit of supporting student success, students in MATH 1120 were surveyed at the beginning and end of the course. They also wrote “mathographies” – autobiographies of their experiences with math. There was a significant improvement in students sense of belonging in math and their growth mindset from the beginning to end of the course. They also reported feeling more confident and interested in both math and computer science at the end of the course.  Students reported increased competence and ability to do math, and the DFW rates in MATH 1120 are lower than in college algebra. While many students take this class only to fulfill the requirement, a number inquired about the “next class” and some went on to take programming courses. The mathographies indicated many students having a positive experience which changed their view of math. For example, one student wrote, "I learned in this course that math is not my enemy and that I have nothing to be afraid of. Thinking in a mathematical way doesn't always involve working out linear equations and graphing."

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 04/29/2022
Modified by: Michelle Friend
por.por_txt_cntn:
The long-term goal of this project is to increase interest, participation, and persistence in the STEM disciplines by transforming how undergraduate students engage with and learn mathematics. In support of this goal we have achieved the following objectives:

MATH 1120: Mathematical and Computational Thinking was developed and approved as general education course. The course teaches math concepts through programming, where the output of the programs is visual art. Enrollment in MATH 1120 has steadily increased. A total of 726 students took the course between Spring 2018 and Spring 2021, taught by five different instructors. The course is popular enough that an instructor was hired into the math department specifically to ensure high quality instruction in this course.
The general education mathematics requirements were revised and renamed to quantitative literacy requirements. In addition to College Algebra (MATH 1220) and MATH 1120, two other new courses (MATH 1130: Quantitative Literacy and MATH 1530: Elementary Statistics) were introduced to meet these requirements. As an outcome of the expansion of gen ed math offerings, many courses across campus expanded their list of math prerequisites beyond college algebra. This opened pathways for students to engage in STEM courses. This was particularly true with introductory computing courses such as CSCI 1200: Computer Science Principles and CIST 1300: Introduction to Web Development but also more broadly, such as PSYCH 3130: Statistics for the Behavioral Sciences. 
The research team worked with Omaha’s Metropolitan Community College and local school districts to offer MATH 1120 beyond UNO, and for UNO credit.


As a research project in pursuit of supporting student success, students in MATH 1120 were surveyed at the beginning and end of the course. They also wrote "mathographies" – autobiographies of their experiences with math. There was a significant improvement in students sense of belonging in math and their growth mindset from the beginning to end of the course. They also reported feeling more confident and interested in both math and computer science at the end of the course.  Students reported increased competence and ability to do math, and the DFW rates in MATH 1120 are lower than in college algebra. While many students take this class only to fulfill the requirement, a number inquired about the "next class" and some went on to take programming courses. The mathographies indicated many students having a positive experience which changed their view of math. For example, one student wrote, "I learned in this course that math is not my enemy and that I have nothing to be afraid of. Thinking in a mathematical way doesn't always involve working out linear equations and graphing."
